page.title: 17THE BLACK WATCH
page.content:
In the 1700s,men were employed by the Government to keep peace in the Highlands.They wore a{dark tartan which became known as the{Black Watch Companies of these men were gathered into a Regiment known as the Black Watch or{42nd Regiment. They first mustered in 1740 on the north bank of the River Tay,opposite Aberfeldy. The{Black Watch Monument}in Aberfeldy} on the south side of the Tay was unveiled in 1887. It takes the form of a cairn on top of which stands a kilted soldier. The Regiment received the{Freedom of {Aberfeldy}in 1970 when they exercised their right to march "with bayonets fixed,drums beating,colours flying'.
The{regimental depot}is now in{Perth.
